Chairman @RepJohnYarmuth: “Our economy cannot afford to permanently lose 1.2 million workers, and women should not be forced to stay out of the workforce because we have failed to respond to very obvious unmet needs in our country."
Chairman @RepJohnYarmuth: “And not all groups have been impacted equally: the unemployment rate for white women is 3.1%. For Latina women it’s 4.8% and for Black women it’s 6.1%”

.@RepJohnYarmuth: "2 yrs later we have made tremendous economic progress but we simply aren’t there yet when it comes to women in the workforce...there are currently 1.2M women missing from the labor force. In contrast the # of men in the labor force is above prepandemic levels."

Chairman @RepJohnYarmuth: "Women also constitute the majority of our frontline workers. So even if they did not lose their jobs, these women faced increased health risks, fewer opportunities for remote work, and a lack of #paidleave."

Chairman @RepJohnYarmuth: "Sectors in which women are overly represented – like education, health services, leisure, and hospitality – saw the greatest job loss to date and have been the slowest to recover."

Chairman @RepJohnYarmuth: "women have been pushed out of the workforce at a shocking rate, losing 12.2M jobs at the depth of the recession. Women accounted for 52% of jobs lost at the peak of the crisis, despite making up only 47% of the labor force at that time."

Chairman @RepJohnYarmuth: "The COVID-19 pandemic and resulting recession raised these barriers even higher, worsening underlying inequities and disparities that have pushed women out of the labor force, compounded their caregiving responsibilities, and more."
Chairman @RepJohnYarmuth: "But despite the progress made & battles won, women - especially women of color - still face systemic barriers to opportunity."

Chairman @RepJohnYarmuth: "From revolutionaries, abolitionists, & suffragists to labor leaders, equal rights activists, & elected officials, women have always been on the frontlines in the fight for progress."

Today her legacy lives on in advanced ranching techniques and in the land around Sarasota, in Meadowsweet Pastures, Myakka River State Park, Osprey Point, Palmer Ranch, The Oaks, and more. #WomensHistoryMonth

While here, this “high society” lady found a passion in agriculture. Palmer worked with scientists and farmers, experimenting with year-round growing techniques and ranching techniques that revolutionized the cattle and hog industries. https://www.visitsarasota.com/article/bertha-palmer-woman-who-tamed-wild-sarasota

Later in her life, she moved to Florida and proved to be a brilliant businesswoman. She advocated for railroad expansions, developing much of the Tampa Bay region and at one point owning a third of Sarasota County. She doubled her wealth.

At the same time, she was a passionate activist for women and children, access to health care, and fair workplaces. At one point, she used her parlor to organize female factory workers and coordinate a strike.

As a Chicago socialite, she lived in a castle one critic called “abominable.” But she was the undisputed center of social life in Chicago and during the 1893 World's Fair helped to build the showcase for women's contributions to business, labor, the arts, industry and science.

A glamorous socialite and renowned businesswoman, Bertha Palmer is credited not only with the invention of the chocolate brownie, but also for groundbreaking farming, ranching, and development here in Florida.  #WomensHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FN_a3izXsAs8fXt.png

RT @SenSchumer The Violence Against Women Act’s expiration 3 years ago put lives in jeopardy.

Since I first help write VAWA, which was in effect from 1994-2019, it saved countless lives.

Now we've reauthorized VAWA to help protect survivors once more.

I was honored to join @POTUS today: https://twitter.com/WhiteHouse/status/1504156938950619145 QT @WhiteHouse Happening Now: President Biden delivers remarks at an event celebrating the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act. https://twitter.com/i/broadcasts/1BdGYwPRjwAxX
Seeing this law reauthorized was a great moment for women and girls everywhere, and I was glad to share it with my friends @RepHoulahan and @RepSpanberger.

As domestic abuse reports rose during the pandemic, these groups have been in touch with me & my team to make clear how important it is they have every tool possible to expand education initiatives, protect the most vulnerable, and help survivors rebuild their lives.
I’m so grateful to the many advocates who fought for this critical legislation, like LACASA in Livingston County, the Women’s Resource Center of Greater Lansing, and HAVEN in Oakland County.

Democrats & Republicans worked together to make sure VAWA is now authorized through 2027, with new & expanded programs like housing protections for victims of violence & the mandatory notification of local law enforcement when a violent offender purchases a gun.

I was at the White House today to celebrate the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) - one of the most important laws passed in the last 30 years - which provides crucial protections for women & girls against violence, and offers support for victims of abuse. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FOALWSGWYAguev0.jpg

So far, the Sentencing Commission has refused to turn over all Judge Jackson’s records from her time there. In light of what we have learned, this stonewalling must end. We must get access to all relevant records

This is a disturbing record for any judge, but especially one nominated to the highest court in the land. Protecting the most vulnerable shouldn’t be up for debate. Sending child predators to jail shouldn’t be controversial.

In United States v. Savage, the sex offender was convicted of travel with intent to engage in illicit sexual conduct, and also admitted to transporting child porn. The Guidelines recommended 46-57 months. Judge Jackson gave him 37.

In United States v. Sears, the sex offender distributed more than 102 child porn videos. He also sent lewd pictures of his own 10-year-old daughter. The Guidelines recommended 97-121 months in prison. Judge Jackson gave him 71 months.

In United States v. Downs, the perp posted multiple images to an anonymous instant messaging app, including an image of a child under the age of 5. The Guidelines recommended 70-87 months. Judge Jackson gave him the lowest sentence allowed by law, 60 months
In United States v. Chazin, the offender had 48 files of child porn, which he had accessed over a period of years. The Guidelines recommended 78-97 months. Judge Jackson gave him 28.

In United States v. Cooper, in which the criminal had more than 600 images and videos and posted many on a public blog, the Guidelines called for a sentence of 151-188 months. Judge Jackson settled on 60 months, the lowest possible sentence allowed by law.

In United States v. Stewart, the criminal possessed thousands of images of child porn and also hoped to travel across state lines to abuse a 9-year-old girl. The Guidelines called for a sentence of 97-121 months. Judge Jackson sentenced the criminal to just 57 months.

In the case of United States v. Hawkins, the sex offender had multiple images of child porn. He was over 18. The Sentencing Guidelines called for a sentence of up to 10 years. Judge Jackson sentenced the perpetrator to only 3 months in prison. Three months.

On the federal bench, Judge Jackson put her troubling views into action. In every single child porn case for which we can find records, Judge Jackson deviated from the federal sentencing guidelines in favor of child porn offenders

In her time on the U.S. Sentencing Commission, Judge Jackson said she “mistakingly assumed that child pornography offenders are pedophiles” and she wanted “to understand this category of nonpedophiles who obtain child pornography.” http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FOAR44_WQAgmlki.jpg

Judge Jackson has opined there may be a type of “less-serious child pornography offender” whose motivation is not sexual but “is the challenge, or to use the technology.” A “less-serious” child porn offender? http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FOAR4pVXIAA7cGs.jpg

Judge Jackson has said that some people who possess child porn “are in this for either the collection, or the people who are loners and find status in their participation in the community.” What community would that be? The community of child exploiters? http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FOAR4aiXIAUrSJ2.jpg

It gets worse. As a member of the U.S. Sentencing Commission, Judge Jackson advocated for drastic change in how the law treats sex offenders by eliminating the existing mandatory minimum sentences for child porn
Judge Jackson has also questioned sending dangerous sex offenders to civil commitment. We have a civil commitment law in Missouri, and it protects children

As far back as her time in law school, Judge Jackson has questioned making convicts register as sex offenders - saying it leads to “stigmatization and ostracism.” She’s suggested public policy is driven by a “climate of fear, hatred & revenge” against sex offenders http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FOAR4D2XIAsSBF-.jpg
